newsitem.title: USA: First Union says fee-based business strong.
newsitem.headline: First Union says fee-based business strong.

text.p: First Union Corp, reporting higher first quarter earnings, said Thursday its fee-based business helped fuel growth in the period.
It cited in particular its capital markets group, where fee-base income was up 67 percent from a year ago.
The company's capital management group increased fee income 61 percent, First Union Chairman Edward Crutchfield said in a statement.
"Considering demographic trends, our entry into new markets and the fact that we are now widely advertising our products, we expect strong sales momentum going forward," he said.

First Union said key factors boosting net income in the first quarter were five percent growth in tax-equivalent net interest income, 47 percent growth in fee income (excluding securities transactions), and good expense control, with an improved efficiency ratio of 56.8 percent.
